DOC.HEAD: Dollar Lower, Stocks Bounce Back
DOC.TEXT: The dollar slipped against the Japanese yen today, while share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange rebounded sharply following the Bank of Japan's decision to raise its discount rate by a half percentage point. The dollar closed at 142.72 yen, down 0.95 yen from Friday's close of 143.67 yen. After opening at 142.72 yen, the currency never moved higher, changing hands between 141.95-142.72 yen in mixed trading. Currency dealers said the dollar's fall followed its weakness in the New York market Friday, affected by factors such as the weakening U.S. economy and expectations of further easing of U.S. interest rates. ``There is a sense in the market that the yen is too weak despite Japan's trade surplus,'' said a dealer at a major Japanese bank, speaking on condition of anonymity. Another dealer with the Bank of Tokyo said there was little movement on the exchange market in early trading, as many overseas markets, including those in the United States, were to stay closed Monday for the Christmas holiday. The Bank of Japan, the nation's central bank, said it decided to raise the discount rate to 4.25 percent from its current level at 3.75 percent. The hike would be put into effect immediately, the bank said. The discount rate is the rate the central bank charges on its loans to commercial banks. The Yomiuri Shimbun, the largest mass-circulation newspaper in Japan, said the central bank's policy board decided to strike a pre-emptive blow against inflationary pressures, stemming from continued high growth in the money supply, upward pressure on land prices and tightness in the labor market. On the Tokyo Stock Exchange, the Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues, which lost 175.11 points Friday, won back 383.25 points, or 0.99 percent, to close at 38,423.62. Securities dealers said share prices were moving in a narrow range during the morning session as investors remained on the sidelines in response to yet unconfirmed reports of the interest rate hike. But once the discount rate hike was announced in the early afternoon, investors enthusiastically placed buy orders. ``The market welcomed the discount rate hike,'' said a dealer at Nikko Securities Co., speaking on condition of anonymity.
